episodes.title: Prince Andrew’s Arrest: The Psychological Twist No One Is Talking About
episodes.description:
Prince Andrew’s arrest has triggered intense public reaction — but what are the deeper psychological implications?

Dr Raj Persaud, consultant psychiatrist in private practice on Harley Street, examines the unexpected mental and strategic dimensions of this fast-moving story. From the King’s rapid distancing statement to the pressures of public disgrace, this discussion explores how psychological manipulation operates in real time — and how crisis can sometimes alter the balance of risk.

Raj considers:

• Whether arrest in the UK may reduce pressure to face more serious proceedings abroad
• The psychological dangers of public humiliation
• Why narcissism can increase — not decrease — the risk of self-harm under stress
• How hopelessness, not scandal, is the key risk factor
• What “reframing” means in psychotherapy during crisis
• And what the choice of barrister might signal about behind-the-scenes support

This analysis does not speculate on guilt or innocence. All individuals are presumed innocent unless proven guilty in a court of law. The focus here is on psychological processes, coping mechanisms, and how extreme public scrutiny affects the human mind.

Shrinking the World brings clinical insight to major cultural and political events — helping viewers understand the psychology beneath the headlines.

episodes.title: Epstein, The Royals & Power: Dr Raj Persaud and Andrew Lownie Investigate
episodes.description:
Newly released Epstein files have reignited questions about the Royal Family, Sarah Ferguson, Prince Andrew and a network of powerful figures whose relationships with Jeffrey Epstein are under renewed scrutiny.

On this episode of Shrinking The World, Dr Raj Persaud — consultant psychiatrist in Harley Street — is joined by historian and royal biographer Andrew Lownie to examine the latest revelations. They explore Fergie’s “marry me” emails, patterns of flattery and intimacy around Epstein, the psychology of entitlement and transactional power, and what these disclosures may mean for the monarchy.

The conversation looks at:

• Why so many high-profile figures appeared unusually close to Epstein
• The psychology of influence, status and boundary-crossing
• Prince Andrew’s position within the wider royal institution
• Whether the Epstein files represent a reputational tipping point
• How elite networks operate behind closed doors

This discussion analyses publicly reported material and released documents. It does not make new allegations. All individuals mentioned are innocent unless proven otherwise.

episodes.title: Prince Andrew, Epstein, and the Psychology of Entitlement | A Psychiatrist with Andrew Lownie
episodes.description:
In this episode of Shrinking the World, consultant psychiatrist Dr Raj Persaud is joined by historian and author Andrew Lownie to examine the psychology behind Jeffrey Epstein’s relationships with powerful and influential figures — including Prince Andrew.

Rather than focusing on allegations or sensational detail, this discussion explores the psychological patterns that appear repeatedly in Epstein’s social world: power, entitlement, flattery, transactional relationships, and the erosion of boundaries among elites who are used to access and privilege.

Topics explored include:

Why influential people appeared unusually close to Epstein

The psychology of entitlement and transactional intimacy

How power can distort judgement and boundaries

Why generosity is sometimes not questioned by those at the top

The difference between personal responsibility and institutional culture

This conversation does not claim to establish private facts or legal conclusions. Instead, it applies psychiatric and psychological frameworks to publicly available material in order to better understand how such relationships can form — and why warning signs may be missed.

⚠️ Disclaimer

This video is an educational discussion of psychology and public behaviour.
It does not diagnose individuals, allege criminal conduct, or claim knowledge of private events. All commentary is based on public reporting and presented for analytical and educational purposes only.
